Description: Redware pottery cosmetic-flask: in the form of a ring, with handles for suspension. The flask has been thrown in at least two parts, joined at base of neck, and is self slipped pale yellow on the outside, and burnished. There is painted decoration between handles comprising a red band filled with diagonal hatched lines below row of black dots. This cosmetic vase has a 'necklace' painted between its handles, a simplified version of a bead collar. One fragment has been re-affixed.
Curator's comments: Dating this flask is difficult. Ring flasks in pottery and stone appear to be a short-lived variant of 'pilgrim flasks', appearing in the middle 18th Dynasty (reign of Tuthmose III, 1490-1436 BC) but going out of fashion before the Amarna period (1364-1347 BC). This flask is certainly of a later date, but no parallel from a securely dated context is known to me. The flask came from the excavations carried out at Abydos in 1925 by Henri Frankfort ('Journal of Egyptian Archaeology' 12 (1926), pp. 157-65; 'Journal of Egyptian Archaeology' 16 (1930), pp. 213-20). Grave 1200 was not published, but the records indicate that a string of beads was the only other object found in the burial. Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, ‘Illahun, Kahun and Gurob’ 1889-1890 (London 1891), pl. xix, 14.
Bibliographic references: Bourriau 1981 / Umm el-Ga'ab: Pottery from the Nile Valley Before the Arab Conquest (149)
Exhibition history: 2022-2023 7 Oct-26 Feb, Middlesbrough, Dorman Museum, NP Ancient Egyptians
